channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Au Pair Testifies of Lurid Plot in Virginia Double-Murder Trial
item.description: Juliana Peres Magalhães wrapped up testimony on Wednesday in the case against Brendan Banfield, her former lover, who is accused of killing his wife and another man.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel
item.media:description: Juliana Peres Magalhães is escorted into the courtroom before continuing her testimony in the trial of Brendan Banfield in Fairfax County, Va., on Wednesday.

item.title: Venezuelan Immigrants Urge Appeals Court to Restore Deportation Protections
item.description: The Trump administration has ended Temporary Protected Status for about 600,000 Venezuelan immigrants, part of a broader effort to curb avenues for immigrants to remain in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Border Servant Corps worker helped a Venezuelan woman who had just crossed the border at El Paso in 2024.

item.title: Federal Agent Shoots Man in Minneapolis, Prompting Tense Protests
item.description: The agent shot a Venezuelan man who was resisting arrest, an official said. Protesters and law enforcement officers clashed for hours, as city officials urged people to go home.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Mitch Smith and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

item.title: 3 More Lawmakers in Video Say Federal Prosecutors Are Investigating Them
item.description: The lawmakers, all Democrats who urged military service members not to follow illegal orders, said prosecutors had contacted them. But it is unclear what crime they might have committed.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Representative Jason Crow of Colorado, one of the lawmakers being investigated, said President Trump was “using his political cronies in the Department of Justice to continue to threaten and intimidate us.”

item.title: Boeing Knew About Flaws in UPS Plane That Crashed in Louisville, N.T.S.B. Says
item.description: In a report Wednesday, the National Transportation Safety Board said fractures that appeared to have led the left engine to separate from the plane’s wing had occurred at least four other times.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: A drone view of the crash site next to a runway at the Muhammad Ali International Airport, after the crash of a UPS cargo plane in Louisville, Ky., last year.

item.title: After Danish and U.S. Officials Meet on Greenland, Trump Remains Unmoved
item.description: Denmark’s foreign minister left the White House complex saying that his country had a “fundamental disagreement” with President Trump, as several NATO countries sent troops to Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen of Denmark, center, and Vivian Motzfeldt, Greenland’s minister of foreign affairs, met with U.S. senators on Wednesday.

item.title: What Voters Told Democrats About ICE, Rising Costs and Party Perceptions
item.description: In focus groups, swing voters gave Democratic politicians some tough feedback on the party.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis.

item.title: Renaming Defense Department Could Cost Taxpayers $125 Million
item.description: A report released by the Congressional Budget Office estimated the amount of money that would be spent on new signs and letterhead, should Congress approve a change.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Department of War placard was displayed on a lectern during a Sept. 11, 2001, commemoration ceremony at the Pentagon in September.

item.title: Congress Is Spurning Many of Trump’s Proposed Spending Cuts
item.description: Months after the partisan clash that led to the longest shutdown in history, lawmakers have agreed on spending bills that look far different from what the president wanted.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: The U.S. Capitol last week. The House voted to pass bills to fund the State and Treasury Departments, as well as other foreign aid programs, providing money for agencies the president had proposed eliminating entirely.

item.title: Newsom Says California Will Not Extradite Abortion Provider to Louisiana
item.description: The case, escalating the interstate battle over abortion, is the second time Louisiana has criminally charged out-of-state doctors with sending abortion pills to Louisiana residents.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: After the Supreme Court eliminated the national right to abortion in 2022, Gov. Gavin Newsom signed an executive order saying that the state would not extradite health providers accused of providing reproductive health services in other states.

item.title: Fine Arts Panel Postpones Review of Trump’s Ballroom
item.description: The Trump administration has been under pressure from preservationists to submit the ballroom project for a formal review.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mirror outside the Oval Office on Tuesday reflects the image of a crane working on the site of the demolished East Wing.

item.title: Trump Administration to Halt Immigrant Visa Processing for 75 Countries
item.description: Federal officials said the move was meant to discourage immigration by people whom they deemed likely to rely on public benefits.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: The pause will affect foreign nationals from countries that include Somalia, Haiti, Iran and Eritrea.

item.title: Federal Judges Uphold California’s New Congressional Maps
item.description: A panel in Los Angeles sided with Gov. Gavin Newsom in a decision that will help Democrats counter Republican gerrymandering in Texas. Republicans are expected to appeal.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California persuaded voters to approve new congressional maps that benefited Democrats. It was a response, he said, to a political gerrymander that helped Republicans in Texas.

item.title: Trump Signs Bill Allowing Schools to Serve Whole Milk Again
item.description: The law, which was approved unanimously by Congress late last year, also gives schools more flexibility in serving nondairy milks.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Will Warasila for The New York Times
item.media:description: An elementary school lunch in Montana in 2024.

item.title: Judge Rejects Effort to Return Man Accused in 9/11 Plot to Guantánamo Trial
item.description: The case of Ramzi bin al-Shibh was severed in 2023 after a military medical panel found him incompetent to help with his defense.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Senate Republicans Block Effort to Check Trump’s War Powers in Venezuela
item.description: G.O.P. leaders succeeded in pressuring fellow senators who initially supported the measure that would have limited President Trump’s military authority in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Senator Josh Hawley, Republican of Missouri, reversed himself on the war powers resolution, saying that Secretary of State Marco Rubio and President Trump convinced him that it was not needed.

item.title: Republicans Advance Stock-Trading Bill With Limited Restrictions
item.description: The bill would allow lawmakers to keep their existing stock and continue to sell it if they provide seven to 14 days of notice. Democrats called it a “gift to insider traders.”
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson at the Capitol last week. He has backed the Stop Insider Trading Act.

item.title: Lawyers for Renee Good’s Family Plan to Investigate Minnesota ICE Shooting
item.description: Ms. Good was killed by an ICE agent last week. Separately, a federal judge put off ruling on a request by the state to block the surge of immigration agents to the Minneapolis area.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:description: Federal agents near the site in Minneapolis where Renee Nicole Good was shot and killed by an agent on Jan. 7.

item.title: Can the ICE Agent Who Shot Renee Good in Minneapolis Be Prosecuted?
item.description: The Trump administration is unlikely to bring a federal case, and any criminal case would face high hurdles. But charges are not out of the question.
item.dc:creator: Shaila Dewan and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: An impromptu memorial sprang up at the site of the killing.

item.title: Supreme Court Sides With Conservative Congressman in Illinois Election Rules Challenge
item.description: The question in the case was not a mail-in ballot rule itself but whether political candidates have the right to challenge the rules governing the vote count in their election.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:description: A vote-by-mail ballot drop box in Chicago. The Illinois case is one of several lawsuits brought by allies of President Trump challenging rules around mail-in ballots after his 2020 election loss.

item.title: Denmark Reinforces Its Military Presence in Greenland
item.description: The Danes say the deployment of aircraft, ships and soldiers is part of an ongoing effort to better protect the island and the Arctic.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Danish ships off Nuuk, Greenland, last year.

item.title: U.S. Weighs Expanding Private Companies’ Role in Cyberwarfare
item.description: The proposal raises a host of questions about the legality and practicality of bolstering the involvement of the private sector in offensive cyberoperations.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of the National Security Agency in Fort Meade, Md. Changing the law to permit private companies to execute offensive cyberattacks would require congressional approval.

item.title: Trump Says Iran Is Stopping Its Killings of Protesters as U.S. Moves Troops
item.description: Nonessential personnel were moved from Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar, an American site that could be a target of Iran if President Trump ordered an attack on the country.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Members of the military at Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar in May.

item.title: Supreme Court Backs Police Entry Without Warrant in Emergencies
item.description: Montana officials defended the actions of law enforcement officers who did not have a warrant when they responded to a possibly suicidal Army veteran.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Janie Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fourth Amendment of the Constitution prohibits unreasonable searches and provides protections for a person’s home by generally prohibiting law enforcement from entering without a warrant.

item.title: F.B.I. Searches Home of Washington Post Journalist in a Leak Investigation
item.description: It is exceedingly rare, even in investigations of the unauthorized disclosure of classified information, for federal agents to search a reporter’s home.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin, Devlin Barrett, Charlie Savage and Erik Wemple
item.media:description: The Washington Post headquarters. Its reporter had spent the past year covering the Trump administration’s effort to fire federal workers.

item.title: A Top Fed Official Says the Trump Administration’s Threats Are ‘About Monetary Policy’
item.description: Neel T. Kashkari, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, defended Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, in an interview. He also said interest rates should be held steady this month.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neel T. Kashkari of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis said the central bank had an opportunity “to explain to our constituents and the American people why Fed independence is so important to the health and the vibrancy of the American economy.”

item.title: Playing Catch on an L.A. Sidewalk? You May (Technically) Risk Jail Time.
item.description: A little-known and rarely enforced law prohibits ball games on some Los Angeles streets and sidewalks. The local council has begun the process of repealing it.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Daniel Dorsa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rarely enforced provision in the Los Angeles Municipal Code prohibits ball games on most streets or sidewalks in the city.

item.title: Chuck Schumer Calls His Shot
item.description: After securing strong recruits on a tough Senate map, the Democratic leader is not only predicting an upset 2026 victory, but also naming the states he thinks his party can flip.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Alex Kent for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York has been under intense pressure within the Democratic Party, but he has managed to secure strong Senate candidates in several top-tier races.

item.title: Trump Credits ‘Mister Tariff’ for the Country’s Strength. Economists Beg to Differ.
item.description: Many indicators appear to suggest that the United States is growing despite tariffs, not because of them.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Trump on Tuesday toured a Ford Motor factory in Dearborn, Mich., and extolled the benefits of tariffs in strengthening the country’s economy.

item.title: How ICE Crackdowns Set Off a Resistance in American Cities
item.description: In Minneapolis and other cities where federal agents have led immigration crackdowns, residents have formed loose networks to track and protest them.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:description: Activists in Minneapolis have been following federal agents as they carry out the Trump administration’s immigration operation.

item.title: An Emboldened Trump Makes Big Bets in Venezuela, Iran and Beyond
item.description: President Trump has left himself plenty of room for maximal intervention. But there are a host of potential wild cards, each with risks for the president.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump has left himself plenty of room for maximal intervention, in Tehran, Caracas and elsewhere.

item.title: Initial Review Finds No Widespread Illegal Voting by Migrants, Puncturing a Trump Claim
item.description: Republican election officials welcome the review, which relies on a federal verification tool, but they say they have not discovered a major problem when it comes to noncitizen voters.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: People vote during the 2024 presidential election in Detroit. Mr. Trump and his allies have claimed for the past decade that elections are riddled with illegal votes cast by undocumented immigrants.
